document.docAuthor: Ferreira, Gabriel S. & Corrêa, Caio C. D. & Monné, Miguel A. & Monné, Marcela L.
document.docTitle: New species of the wasp-mimic Parahephaestion Melzer, 1930 (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae), from Minas Gerais, Brazil, with new records

emphasis.docTitle:
New species of the wasp-mimic
Parahephaestion Melzer, 1930
( Coleoptera : Cerambycidae ), from Minas Gerais , Brazil , with new records

subSection.paragraph:
GABRIEL S. FERREIRA 1,* , CAIO C. D. CORRÊA 2,4 , MIGUEL A. MONNÉ 2,5 & MARCELA L. MONNÉ 2,3
1
Laboratório de Entomologia, Departamento de Zoologia, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro , Av. Carlos Chagas Filho, 373, CEP 21941-599, Rio de Janeiro , RJ, Brazil
Ễ gdsferreira1@gmail.com; https://orcid.org/0000-0002-4228-9100

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Departamento de Entomologia, Museu Nacional, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro – UFRJ, Quinta da Boa Vista, São Cristóvão , CEP 20940–040, Rio de Janeiro , RJ, Brazil
Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico—CNPq

subSection.paragraph: Ễ mlmonne2@gmail.com; https://orcid.org/0000-0003-2103-4878

4
Ễ
caio.entomologia@gmail.com ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0002-4877-617X

5
Ễ
monne@uol.com.br ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0001-8825-3122

A new species,
Parahephaestion mimicus
sp. nov.
, is described. Two species are newly recorded for the Brazilian state of Minas Gerais :
Sphalloeme costipennis Melzer, 1928
( Cerambycinae , Oemini ) and
Oreodera omissa Melzer, 1932
( Lamiinae , Acrocinini ). Six species are new records for the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça, ( Brazil , Minas Gerais ):
Thalusia atrata (Melzer, 1918)
( Cerambycinae , Rhopalophorini ),
Trachelissa pustulata (Audinet-Serville, 1834)
( Cerambycinae , Trachyderini ),
Ateralphus dejeani (Lane, 1973) (Lamiinae, Acanthoderini)
,
Phacellocera plumicornis (Klug, 1825)
( Lamiinae , Anisocerini ),
Oncideres impluviata (Germar, 1823)
, and
Psyllotoxus griseocinctus Thomson, 1868
( Lamiinae, Onciderini ).
Key word: Longhorn beetles, Pompilidae, Neotropical, Batesian mimicry, Necydalinae

Eight subfamilies have been historically included in Cerambycidae : Cerambycinae , Dorcasominae , Lamiinae, Lepturinae , Necydalinae , Parandrinae , Prioninae , and
Spondylidinae (
Haddad et al . 2018
)
. More recently, Necydalinae and Parandrinae have been recognized as part of Lepturinae and Prioninae , respectively, reducing the number of subfamilies to six (
Nie et al . 2021
).

Hephaestion ( Parahephaestion ) Melzer, 1930
( Cerambycinae ) was proposed to include Brazilian species with elytra bearing costae and metatibiae with dense tuft of short and erect setae.
Hephaestion ( Hephaestion ) Newman, 1840
, included species distributed only in the Andean Patagonian region. Monné & Giesbert (1994) considered
Parahephaestion
a distinct genus. Currently,
Parahephaestion
has three species:
P. brasiliensis (Melzer, 1923)
,
P. malleri ( Melzer, 1930 )
, and
P. zikani (Melzer, 1923) ( Monné 2024c )
.

According to Švácha & Lawrence (2014) , there is extensive parallelism in the morphology of the adults of Cerambycinae . They listed
Necydalis Linnaeus, 1758
and
Ulochaetes LeConte, 1854
in Necydalinae and considered that probably the other genera were misclassified. Monné (2024c) included
Parahephaestion
in Necydalinae and Tavakilian & Chevillotte (2024) in Cerambycinae incertae sedis .

Vulcano et al . (1980)
provided the first list of the Cerambycidae from the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça, including 83 species. Monné & Monné (2017) described
Adesmus lauropalui Monné & Monné, 2017
(Hemilophini) and listed 254 species from the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça, of which 158 were new distributional records.
Coleoxestia pubicornis (Gounelle, 1909)
and
Nyssicostylus subopacus Bates, 1885
were registered to the RPPN ( Martins & Monné 2004 ; Martins 2005 ) but not listed in Monné & Monné (2017) . Therefore, a total of 256 species are recorded from the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça.

Longhorn beetle diversity at the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça, Minas Gerais , was investigated between November 17th and 23rd, 2022 . The results of the survey have increased the number Cerambycidae species recorded for the RPPN to 265. Herein, we described a new species of
Parahephaestion
and added eight new distributional records for the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça, of which, two are new state records for Minas Gerais , Brazil .

A survey of the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça, in Minas Gerais , was conducted between November 17th and 23rd, 2022 . The material was collected with light traps (Luiz de Queiroz model), active search, and white cloth trapping. The specimens were identified by comparing them with the original descriptions and redescriptions, and the photographs of type specimens available on Bezark (2024) .

Specimens were photographed using a Leica DFC 500 digital camera attached to a Leica MZ16 stereoscope, and images were edited using the computer software Leica LAS 3D Viewer and LAS Montage v. 4.7. The photographs were further edited in Adobe Photoshop. The photos of the other species of
Parahephaestion
were taken using a Canon EOS TD Mark II camera, Canon MP-E 65 mm f/2.8 1–5X macro lens, controlled by Zerene Stacker AutoMontage software.

The terminology follows
Lawrence et al. (2010)
. Geographic distribution follows
Souza et al . (2021)
, Monné’s catalog (2024a, b, c), and database by Tavakilian & Chevillotte (2024) . All specimens are deposited in the MNRJ (see acronym below).
The acronyms used in the text are as follows:

CEIOC —Coleção Entomológica da Fundação Oswaldo Cruz, Fundação Oswaldo Cruz, Rio de Janeiro , Brazil . DZUP—Coleç„o Entomológica Padre Jesus Santiago Moure, Universidade Federal do Paraná , Brazil . MCNZ—Museu de Ciências Naturais, Fundaç„o Zoobotânica do Rio Grande do Sul , Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul , Brazil .
MNRJ —Museu Nacional, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro , Rio de Janeiro , Brazil .
MZSP —Museu de Zoologia, Universidade de S„o Paulo, S„o Paulo, Brazil .
RPPN —Reserva Particular de Patrimônio Natural Sanctuary do Caraça, Catas Altas, Minas Gerais , Brazil .

Fifty-three species ( 119 specimens ) of longhorn beetles were collected at the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça, Minas Gerais , Brazil . Of them, a new species of
Parahephaestion
is described and eight species are new distribution records from RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça. Two species are new state records for Minas Gerais .

subSubSection.paragraph:
Description. Holotype female
( Figs. 1A–C ). Coloration. Integument mostly black; apex of antennomere VI and antennomeres VII and XI brown, except yellowish base of antennomere XI, antennomeres VIII–X yellow; elytra tricolorous, black with dark blue reflections on anterior fifth, mostly dark brown on second anterior fifth, yellowishbrown on remaining surface, except narrow, longitudinal yellow bands dorsally, more distinct between anterior fifth and posterior third, and blackish apex and most of sutural and epipleural margins. Wings brown with blackish areas. Head. Distance between upper eye lobes about 0.9 times length of scape. Head with median groove deep, well-marked from clypeus to vertex. Frons with thin and dense punctation; with short black setae. Vertex with dense and shallow punctation; with dense, short, erect black setae. Clypeus and gena with sparse, long black setae. Labrum with sparse, long, both black and yellow setae. Mandible with sparse, thin, shallow punctation and long black setae. Antennal tubercles well developed, with dense, shallow punctation. Antennae with 11 antennomeres, reaching elytral middle; scape cylindrical, with dense, shallow punctation; antennomere III about as long as scape; antennomere IV shorter than III; antennomere V longer than IV; VI–X with subequal length; antennomeres III– V filiform; antennomeres VI–X thickened and slightly serrate; antennomere XI elongated; scape, pedicel, and antennomeres III–V covered with black setae; antennomeres VI covered by thin white pubescence; antennomeres VIII–X covered with thin golden pubescence; antennomeres VII and XI covered with brown pubescence. Thorax. Prothorax wider than long, constricted anteriorly; sides with large, conical tubercle with blunt apex. Pronotum with four tubercles: two elevated, rounded apically, located slightly before middle and two smalls on posterior half; covered with dense, short, erect black setae. Prosternum microsculptured, with transverse wrinkles on anterior half; with sparse, long black setae. Prosternal process narrow, rounded apically; apex with erect black setae. Mesoventrite microsculptured, with transverse wrinkles; with sparse, long black setae. Mesoventral process wide, with notched apex. Mesanepisternum, mesepimeron, metaventrite, metanepisternum, and metepimeron microsculptured, with shallow punctation; with sparse, long black setae. Scutellum triangular, rounded apically; without longitudinal sulcus; with sparse, short black setae. Elytra. Dehiscent, reaching apex of ventrite 3, abruptly tapering from medial third to apex; anterior half wider than posterior area of prothorax; with three longitudinal dorsal costae, starting on anterior third and disappearing before apex; with deep sulcus on anterior third of dorsal surface; with sparse, short, both black and brown setae. Legs. With black setae. Profemora subfusiform; meso- and metafemora subclavate; mesofemora distinctly shorter than metafemora; metafemora reaching apex of ventrite 4. Mesotibiae slightly elongated, about as long as mesofemora; metatibiae elongated, longer than metafemora, with dense tuft of short and erect black setae. Metatarsi elongated; metatarsomere I about two times longer than II+III. Abdomen. Subcylindrical and microsculptured; ventrite 1 subglabrous; ventrites 2–5 covered with dense, long, decumbent whitish pubescence; ventrite 5 triangular; apical margin rounded.

Paratype male
( Figs. 1D–F ). Integument totally black; distance between upper eye lobes about 0.8 times length of scape; antennae surpass the apex of ventrite 5 on middle at antennomere X; antennomeres V–XI with subequal length; antennomeres VI–X slender and serrate; scape, pedicel, and antennomeres III–V with black setae; VI–XI glabrous. Prothorax slightly wider than long. Prosternum with sparse yellow setae. Apex of prosternal process with yellow setae. Mesoventrite, mesanepisternum, mesepimeron, metaventrite, and posterior half of metepimeron covered with short yellow setae. Elytra reaching the anterior margin of ventrite 4; surface without dorsal costae. Metatarsomere I longer than twice length of II+III. Central region of ventrites subglabrous; lateral margins with white setae. Ventrite 5 subquadrate.

Measurements, in mm ( holotype female/ paratype male).
Total length, 29.6/21.0; prothoracic length, 4.5/2.8; anterior prothoracic width, 4.1/2.5; posterior prothoracic width, 4.5/2.6; widest prothoracic width, 6.1/3.4; humeral width, 6.3/3.4; elytral length, 19.5/12.5.

Type material.
Holotype : Female , Brazil , Minas Gerais : Catas Altas , RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça , Trilha Banho do Belchior , 20°6’51.96”S 43°29’34.44”W ,
1271m
,
19.xi.2022
, coleta manual, Ferreira, G.S. , Monné, M.L. leg. ( MNRJ-ENT7-47239 )
.
Paratype : Male, same data as holotype ( MNRJ-ENT7-47240 )
.

Etymology. The specific name
“ mimicus
” (mimic) comes from Latin, in reference to the fact that the new species mimics spider wasps ( Hymenoptera : Pompilidae ).

Remarks . The species of
Parahephaestion
are possibly known only by the type specimens. We checked four Brazilian collections (CEIOC, DZUP, MCNZ and MZSP) and we only found type material at the MZSP.

The genus now presents four species: 1)
P. brasiliensis
( Figs. 2A–B ), known only for the male holotype, from Passa Quatro, Minas Gerais, Brazil; 2)
P. zikani
( Figs. 2E–F ), known only for two females (lectotype, paralectotype), from Passa Quatro, Minas Gerais, Brazil; 3)
P. malleri
( Figs. 2C–D ), known only for the female holotype, from Itaiópolis, Santa Catarina, Brazil ; and 4)
P. mimicus
sp. nov.
, described in this study.

Parahephaestion mimicus
sp. nov.
can be differentiated from the congeneric species by the coloration ( Figs. 1A–F , Figs. 2A–F ); antennae in males, reaching the apex of ventrite 5; pronotum with four tubercles; and scutellum without longitudinal sulcus. In
P. brasiliensis
( Figs. 2A–B ),
P. malleri
( Figs. 2C–D ), and
P. zikani
( Figs. 2E–F ) the pronotum presents five tubercles and the scutellum has longitudinal sulcus. In
P. brasiliensis
, the antennae surpass the abdominal apex by two antennomeres.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1A–F.
Parahephaestion mimicus
sp. nov.
Habitus. Holotype female, A–C: A—Dorsal; B—Lateral; C—Ventral. Paratype male, D–F: D—Dorsal; E—Lateral; F—Ventral. Scale bars: (A–C) 5 mm, (D–F) 4 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Parahephaestion mimicus
sp. nov.
is the first species of the genus represented in the literature by male and female ( Figs. 1A–F ). There is sexual dimorphism mainly in the color of the antennae and elytra and the body shape: females are slender than males. Similar dimorphism can be observed in
P. brasiliensis
[male] ( Figs. 2A–B ) and
P. zikani
[female] ( Figs. 2E–F ), both collected in Passa Quatro, MG (at different years), which may indicate that it could be the same species. More specimens are needed to confirm the possible synonym.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2A–G. Species of
Parahephaestion
and wasp of the tribe Pepsini ( Hymenoptera , Pompilidae ). A–B,
Parahephaestion brasiliensis (Melzer, 1923)
, male holotype (MZSP): A—Dorsal view, B—Ventral view. C–D,
Parahephaestion malleri ( Melzer, 1930 )
, female holotype (MZSP): C—Dorsal view, D—Ventral view. E–F,
Parahephaestion zikani (Melzer, 1923)
, female lectotype (MZSP): E—Dorsal view, F—Ventral view. G, Hymenoptera , Pompilidae , Pepsini —Dorsal view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Biological note. Some groups of Cerambycidae that are wasp-mimicking ( e.g., some Clytini and some Rhinotragini ( Cerambycinae ),
Atelopteryx Lacordaire, 1869
,
Hephaestion Newman, 1840
,
Necydalis Linnaeus, 1758
, and
Ulochaetes LeConte, 1854
), are similar in behavior, coloration, and morphology ( Linsley 1959 ). For example, Barriga & Peña (1994) described
Callisphyris pepsioides
and discussed the similarity with wasps of the genus
Pepsis Fabricius, 1804
[ Hymenoptera : Pompilidae ]. The species of
Parahephaestion
has morphological similarities with wasp, with elongated body, short antennae and dehiscent or short elytra (resemble the spider wasp’s wings). The male and female of
P. mimicus
sp. nov.
were found in copulation under a leaf during daytime. At first glance, we thought they were Pompilidae [ Hymenoptera ] in copulation but later we realized they belonged to Cerambycidae . On the same day, we collected one specimen of the tribe Pepsini [ Hymenoptera : Pompilidae ] ( Fig. 2G ) on the same trail (Trilha Banho do Belchior), which has the same color pattern of the body, including antennae as in the female of the new species.

subSection.paragraph: Below is the list of new distributional records, including precise localities and literature information. Records are organized by subfamily, tribe, subtribe, genus, and species, with the latter in alphabetical order, as follows:

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. BRAZIL ( Bahia , Espírito Santo , Rio de Janeiro , S„o Paulo, Paraná , Santa Catarina , and Rio Grande do Sul ), and ARGENTINA (Misiones). We added a new state record from Minas Gerais, Brazil .

Material examined.
BRAZIL , Minas Gerais , Catas Altas , RPPN
Sanctuary of Caraça , Trilha Tanque Grande , 20°6’5.58”S 43°29’32.34”W ,
1201 m
, light trap , male,
18–23.xi.2022
, Monné, M.L. leg ( MNRJ-ENT7-47246 )
.

Diagnosis. This species is recognized by the following combination of characters: clypeus triangular; maxillary palpi elongated, palpomere III 3.0 times longer than II; pedicel as long as half the length of the scape; antennomere III shorter than IV ( Martins 1997 ).
Distribution. BRAZIL ( Minas Gerais and Espírito Santo ). Here we recorded it for the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça.

Material examined.
BRAZIL , Minas Gerais , Catas Altas , RPPN
Sanctuary of Caraça , Trilha Tanque Grande , 20°6’5.58”S 43°29’32.34”W ,
1201 m
, male,
18.xi.2022
, Monné, M.L. leg. ( MNRJ-ENT7-47245 )
.

Diagnosis. This species is recognized by the following combination of characters: antennae and legs black; metafemora abruptly and robustly clavate; metatibiae with sulcus and carinae evident on posterior half; metatibiae with tuft of setae ( Marques & Napp 1996 ).
Distribution. BRAZIL ( Bahia , Minas Gerais , Mato Grosso , Goiás , Espírito Santo , Rio de Janeiro , S„o Paulo, and Paraná ). Here we recorded it for the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça.

Material examined.
BRAZIL , Minas Gerais , Catas Altas , RPPN
Sanctuary of Caraça ,
Casa da Ponte
, 20°5’55.10”S 43°29’24.83”W ,
1287 m
, female,
18.xi.2022
, Monné, M.L. leg. ( MNRJ-ENT7-47247 )
.

Diagnosis. This species is recognized by the following combination of characters: shiny body surface; antennomere III with a longitudinal sulcus (male); antennomere XII about half the length of III (male) and antennomere XI about half the length of III (female); prothorax about as long as wide; pronotum with a pair of tubercles near the posterior margin; elytra about 3 times as long as prothorax; elytra glabrous with sparse, fine punctures ( Quintino & Monné 2014: 504 , figs. 122–132).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3A–H. New records in Cerambycidae . Dorsal habitus. A—
Sphalloeme costipennis Melzer, 1928
; B—
Thalusia atrata (Melzer, 1918)
; C—
Trachelissa pustulata (Audinet-Serville, 1834)
; D—
Ateralphus dejeani (Lane, 1973)
; E—
Oreodera omissa Melzer, 1932
; F—
Phacellocera plumicornis (Klug, 1825)
; G—
Oncideres impluviata (Germar, 1823)
; H—

.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. FRENCH GUIANA , GUYANE , BRAZIL ( Bahia , Goiás , Minas Gerais , Espírito Santo , Rio de Janeiro , S„o Paulo, Paraná , Santa Catarina , and Rio Grande do Sul ), ARGENTINA (Misiones), and PARAGUAY ( Alto Paraná ). Here we recorded it for the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça.

Material examined.
BRAZIL , Minas Gerais , Catas Altas , RPPN
Sanctuary of Caraça , Trilha Banho do Belchior , 20°6’51.96”S 43°29’34.44”W ,
1271 m
, Malaise, male,
18–23.xi.2022
, Monné, M.L. leg. ( MNRJ-ENT7-47243 )
.

Diagnosis. This species is recognized by the following combination of characters: pronotum with slightly prominent posterolateral elevations toward the median tubercles; elytra with longitudinal carinae evident, with patches of dense and salient white setae irregularly distributed; region between elytral basal-crests covered with dense light brown setae also covering the scutellum, forming a circum-scutellar macula; meso- and metafemora glabrous on inner surface ( Souza & Monné, 2013: 329 , figs. 101, 102).
Distribution. BRAZIL ( Goiás , Espírito Santo , Rio de Janeiro , S„o Paulo, and Santa Catarina ). We added a new state record from Minas Gerais , Brazil.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
BRAZIL , Minas Gerais , Catas Altas , RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça ,
Casa da Ponte
, 20°5’55.10”S 43°29’24.83”W ,
1287 m
, pano branco com luz, 1 male ( MNRJ-ENT7-47249 ), 2 females ( MNRJ-ENT7-47248 , MNRJ-ENT7-47250),
21.xi.2022
, Monné, M.L. leg.

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. This species is recognized by the following combination of characters: elytra with grayish pubescence, irregular, large, oblique (wave) dark macula laterocentrally, and large dark macula on sides of the apical third; elytra with sparse and fine punctures, denser basally; humeri with lateral tubercle; metatibiae covered with black pubescence except whitish large median band.
Distribution. BRAZIL ( Minas Gerais , Espírito Santo , Rio de Janeiro , S„o Paulo, and Santa Catarina ). Here we recorded it for the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça.

Material examined.
BRAZIL , Minas Gerais , Catas Altas , RPPN
Sanctuary of Caraça , Trilha Banho do Belchior , 20°6’51.96”S 43°29’34.44”W ,
1271 m
, female, Malaise,
18-23.xi.2022
, Monné, M.L. leg. ( MNRJ-ENT7-47244 )
.

Diagnosis. This species is recognized by the following combination of characters: apex of antennomeres IV with tuft of setae on inner margin; sides of prothorax with conical tubercle; mesosternal process without tubercles; elytra with two tubercles, one on anterior center and another on the posterior fifth ( Galileo & Martins 1998 ).

Distribution. BRAZIL ( Bahia , Goiás , Minas Gerais , Rio de Janeiro , S„o Paulo, Paraná , Santa Catarina , and Rio Grande do Sul ), PARAGUAY , ARGENTINA (Misiones, Córdoba ), and URUGUAY . Here we recorded if for the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça.

Material examined.
BRAZIL , Minas Gerais , Catas Altas , RPPN
Sanctuary of Caraça , Trilha Banho do Belchior , 20°6’51.96”S 43°29’34.44”W ,
1271 m
, male, Malaise,
18–23.xi.2022
, Monné, M.L. leg. ( MNRJ-ENT7-47241 )
.

Diagnosis. This species is recognized by the following combination of characters: antennal tubercle not projected; sides of prothorax with acute postmedian tubercle; elytra covered by spots of orangish pubescence, base with shiny black granules.

Distribution. FRENCH GUIANA and BRAZIL ( Minas Gerais , Espírito Santo , Rio de Janeiro , S„o Paulo, Paraná , Santa Catarina , and Rio Grande do Sul ). Here we recorded it for the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça.

Material examined.
BRAZIL , Minas Gerais , Catas Altas , RPPN
Sanctuary of Caraça , trilha Tanque Grande , 20°6’5.58”S 43°29’32.34”W ,
1201 m
, male, light trap ,
20.xi.2022
, Monné, M.L. leg. ( MNRJ-ENT7-47242 )
.

Diagnosis. This species is recognized by the following combination of characters: eyes with lower lobes distinctly shorter than gena; antennal tubercles (male) armed at apex with short, blunt horn; antennomere III (male) distinctly swollen, strongly clavate ( Nearns & Tavakilian 2012 ).

subSection.paragraph:
As was observed sexual dimorphism between the male and the female of
Parahephaestion mimicus
sp. nov.
, we believe that collecting more specimens of
Parahephaestion
is necessary to better understand the delimitation between its species and if the accentuated sexual dimorphism also occurs in other species.

Two hundred and fifty-six species of Cerambycidae were known from the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça. After the description of
Parahephaestion mimicus
sp. nov.
and eight new records from the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça, the diversity increased to 265 species.
Our results revealed undiscovered Cerambycidae species within the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça, highlighting the need for more efforts to collect specimens in this region.

The authors are grateful to “Programa de Pós-graduaç„o em Zoologia, Museu Nacional, UFRJ” for the financial support and Dr. Pedro G. Dias for organizing the field work. We also thank Antonio Santos-Silva ( MZSP ) for confirming the identification of some specimens and for the photos of the other species of
Parahephaestion
deposited at the MZSP . This work was supported by Coordenaç„o de Aperfeiçoamento de Pessoal de Nível Superior - Brasil (CAPES) (88887.661071/2022-00—GSF; 23038.004195/2022-59), Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico (142460/2019-2—CCDC; CNPq grant 305584/2022-7—MLM), and Fundaç„o Carlos Chagas Filho de Amparo à Pesquisa do Estado do Rio de Janeiro (201.657/2021—CCDC; E-26/010.001394/2019). Thanks also to David Guevara-Apaza (Crees Foundation) for helping identify the wasp. We thank anonymous reviewer.

paragraph.bibRef:
